text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two horizontally aligned narrative miniatures arranged in registers, each contained within simple double-line frames; full-page spread with no accompanying text, providing clear separation between the two scenes and emphasizing visual hierarchy through register placement.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for halos and divine attributes; red and green garments alternate to denote key figures; ultramarine and azurite blues used for halos and background framing; layered pigment application with white lead highlights on drapery folds; harmonious color repetition between registers; original hues remain vibrant with minimal pigment darkening.

features: Horizontal alignment of figures around central divine figures
Hierarchical scaling of Mary and Christ larger than surrounding characters
Clear visual flow top to bottom guiding viewer through story

decorative_elements: Double-line colored border frames in red, blue and gold
Simple geometric framing without vegetal scrollwork
Uniform gold halos as unifying symbol
Linear bench architecture in upper register
Plain parchment ground allowing focus on figures

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill ink outlines with consistent weight and occasional reinforced contour strokes
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with minimal hatching, white lead highlights on fabric creases
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping figures suggest depth without true linear perspective

reading_order: Upper register (Adoration of the Magi) first
Lower register (Presentation in the Temple) second

scene_relationships.subject: Adoration of the Magi
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to the Presentation of Christ in the Temple, completing the Christ child’s ritual and prophetic recognition
visual_connections: Mary’s red robe mirrored in lower register garments
Consistent gold halos linking divine figures
Green mantle of Mary reused in lower scene
Similar drapery fold treatment across registers
Repetition of kneeling gesture echoing humility theme

scene_relationships.subject: Presentation of Christ in the Temple
visual_connections: White cloth in upper and lower scenes
Consistent bench-like base in both registers

visual_continuity: Ultramarine and verdigris green color palette in both registers

content_theme.scene_description:
In the upper register (Adoration of the Magi), five figures occupy a single horizontal band against a plain parchment ground. At the right, the Virgin Mary sits on a low bench, clad in a red gown with green mantle, holding the naked Christ child with a blue halo. Directly before her kneels the eldest Magus, offering a rectangular gilt chest; his robes are violet lined with ochre. Two standing crowned Magi flank him to the left: the first holds a spherical censer, the second a gold vessel; both wear long gowns of yellow and violet with green cloaks. All magi exhibit naturalistic faces, long hair and beards, their robes articulated with white lead highlights. Mary’s head is inclined toward the child, whose arm reaches out. Figures overlap slightly to suggest spatial depth. 

Secondary Elements: The lower register (Presentation in the Temple) sits directly beneath, separated by a narrow band, and depicts five figures: from left, two female attendants holding baskets of doves, the Virgin Mary in center handing the Christ child to the elderly priest Simeon at right. This connects narratively and visually to the upper scene through repeated color motifs and drapery style. The uniform framing integrates both scenes into a coherent visual program. 

Visual-Textual Relationships: No text is present; the miniatures occupy the full page. The decorative frames act as visual separators and guides, directing the viewer’s eye sequentially. The absence of captions heightens reliance on iconographic conventions to convey narrative.

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum with smooth, lustrous finish; evidence of professional scraping and pumicing; regular quire structure with consistent margins.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent preservation; vibrant pigments with minimal oxidation; slight surface cockling at edges; negligible pigment flaking in red areas; no major abrasions.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf halos
Fine underdrawing visible under infrared reflecting drapery contours
Layered brush strokes in flesh tones
Burnished gold leaf with punch-dot embellishment

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual noble patron for private devotional use

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This bifoliate miniature likely originates from a mid-14th-century French book of hours, produced in a Parisian workshop renowned for its refined use of gold leaf and ultramarine. The dual-register composition reflects a popular devotional sequence, presenting the Epiphany followed by the Purification and Presentation in the Temple as complementary episodes in the Christ child’s early life. The absence of accompanying text suggests these images served both mnemonic and meditative functions, guiding the viewer through a visual liturgy. Stylistically, the naturalistic modeling of faces and the delicate underdrawing visible beneath the rich pigments point to a collaborative atelier, where a master applied the key outlines and apprentices executed color. The sophisticated layering of white lead highlights atop saturated reds and greens demonstrates advanced technical mastery and a high-quality vellum support. Iconographically, the symmetrical arrangement and hierarchical scaling emphasize Mary’s centrality, while the repeated use of gold halos and color echoes between registers unites the narrative. Comparative analysis with the Hours of Jeanne d’Evreux reveals similar treatment of drapery folds and framing devices, suggesting either the same workshop or a closely associated circle. This miniature exemplifies the transitional illumination style in Paris circa 1340–50, balancing inherited Gothic conventions with emerging naturalism and a heightened emotional engagement appropriate for private devotion.
